sections.title: Monitor & Control Overview
sections.markdown:
Monitor & Control activities run throughout the duration of the project, but peak during the Executing Phase. All project management processes are executed as part of the Monitor & Control process group.
The Monitor & Control activities are carried out based on the processes described in the Project Management Plans developed during the Planning Phase. The effective execution of these processes is ultimately the responsibility of the Project Manager (PM).

### Manage

- Execute all management processes defined in the Project Management Plans, and manage the outsourcing, transition, business implementation and deliverables acceptance activities as per the relevant Project Specific Plans.

### Monitor

- Monitor project activities and overall project performance.
- Track the project performance against the baseline in order to facilitate reporting and controlling.

### Control

- Devise, plan, propose and implement corrective actions to address existing or potential performance risks or issues, while updating the relevant project plans and logs.

![](/pm2/figures/fig-9-1.png)

**Fig 9.1** Monitor & Control activities and main artefacts
Monitor & Control artefacts comprise the Project Work Plan as well as a range of Project Logs and Checklists.
The **Project Logs** are regularly updated as new information becomes available (e.g. new issues can arise and new information can be added to the Issue Log).
There are several **Checklists** that can be used to help the Project Manager (PM) control the project better.

#### PM² provides the following Checklists:

- Phase-exit Review Checklist
- Quality Review Checklist
- Deliverables Acceptance Checklist
- Transition Checklist
- Stakeholders Checklist
- Business Implementation Checklist

sections.title: Monitor Project Performance
sections.markdown:
The purpose of project performance monitoring is to collect information about the state of the project's progress and overall health. The Project Manager (PM) tracks the project dimensions of scope, schedule, cost and quality, monitors risks, issues and project change, and forecasts their evolution for the purpose of reporting the overall project progress.
This information is then distributed to relevant stakeholders as per the Communications Management Plan.

**Key Participants**

| Participant | Description |
|-------------|-------------|
| Project Manager (PM) | Undertakes all project monitoring activities. |
| Project Core Team (PCT) | Contributes information on project progress. |

#### Inputs

- Project Handbook
- Project Work Plan
- Project Logs (Risk Log, Issue Log, Decision Log, Project Change Log)
- Quality Checklist
- Minutes of Meetings (MoMs)
- Input from the Contractor's Project Manager (CPM), if applicable

#### Steps

1. Use the baselined Project Work Plan as a reference for monitoring project performance.
2. Regularly exchange information about the project's current status and next steps with the Project Core Team (PCT) at formal and informal meetings.
3. Gather information on, and monitor the progress of:
   - **Tasks** — status of critical and next-critical-path tasks.
   - **Key outputs** — completed/verified deliverables and milestone achievement.
   - **Resource utilisation** — resources used as planned and costs as budgeted.
   - **Logs** — status and evolution of risks, issues, changes and decisions.
   - **People** — team morale, stakeholder engagement, overall dynamics and productivity.

![](/pm2/figures/fig-9-2.png)

**Fig 9.2** Monitor Project Performance inputs/outputs and main roles

**Outputs**

- Project Work Plan (tracked) ☑

sections.title: Control Schedule
sections.markdown:
The purpose of schedule control is to ensure that project tasks are carried out as scheduled and that project deadlines are met. The Project Manager (PM) regularly monitors the schedule and tracks the difference between planned, actual and forecast activities/deadlines.
Approved project changes that impact the overall project schedule are incorporated into the Project Work Plan (updated schedule). If delays exceed thresholds, the PSC must be informed and corrective actions defined.

**Key Participants**

| Participant | Description |
|-------------|-------------|
| Project Manager (PM) | Monitors and controls the work schedule. |
| Project Core Team (PCT) | Works to keep to the baselined schedule and standards; reports status. |

#### Inputs

- Project Handbook
- Project Work Plan
- Change Log and other relevant Logs
- MoMs and previous Project Reports

#### Steps

1. Track task evolution per the Project Handbook.
2. Update the project schedule to reflect actual task status.
3. Review the Project Work Plan regularly for potential delays.
4. Track changes, issues and risks for schedule impact.
5. Devise/agree/implement corrective actions for significant deviations.
6. Inform affected stakeholders of schedule or task changes.

![](/pm2/figures/fig-9-3.png)

**Fig 9.3** Control Schedule inputs/outputs and main roles

**Outputs**

- Project Work Plan (updated) ☑
- Project Logs (updated) ☑

sections.title: Control Cost
sections.markdown:
The purpose of cost control is to manage the project costs so that they conform to the cost/effort baseline and overall project budget constraints. The Project Manager (PM) regularly monitors the budget and tracks the difference between budgeted, actual and expected costs.
If the project budget is at risk, the PSC must be informed and corrective actions agreed and implemented. Significant overruns require justification and approval from the PO or AGB.
**Note:** The project budget must have been approved by the PO at project start.

**Key Participants**

| Participant | Description |
|-------------|-------------|
| Project Manager (PM) | Monitors and controls the budget. |
| Project Owner (PO) | Owns and approves the budgeted costs. |

#### Inputs

- Project Handbook
- Project Work Plan
- Outsourcing Plan (if applicable)
- Change Log and other Project Logs
- MoMs and past Project Reports

#### Steps

1. Track the project's budget consumption using the agreed approach.
2. Regularly review the project budget with the PO.
3. Evaluate and communicate differences between budgeted and actual costs.
4. Devise and plan corrective actions when required.
5. If the budget must be revised, justify and secure formal approval.
6. Assess impact on schedule, risks or quality and communicate as needed.

![](/pm2/figures/fig-9-4.png)

**Fig 9.4** Control Cost inputs/outputs and main roles

**Outputs**

- Project Work Plan (updated) ☑
- Project Logs (updated) ☑

sections.title: Manage Stakeholders
sections.markdown:
Managing project stakeholders is a critical activity that starts in the Initiating Phase and ends in the Closing Phase when stakeholders' overall experience and satisfaction are documented.
While the PM is responsible, the PSC and BM play important supporting roles.

**Key Participants**

| Participant | Description |
|-------------|-------------|
| Project Manager (PM) | Manages project stakeholders. |
| Business Manager (BM) | Assists the PM in stakeholder management. |

#### Inputs

- Project Handbook
- Project Stakeholder Matrix
- Communications Management Plan
- Deliverables Acceptance & Transition Plans
- Business Implementation Plan

#### Steps

1. Analyse expectations, influence and interest of key stakeholders.
2. Devise communication and management strategies.
3. Monitor stakeholder attitudes and manage accordingly.
4. Ensure management activities are time-bound and focused.
5. Align Communications Management Plan with stakeholder needs.

![](/pm2/figures/fig-9-5.png)

**Fig 9.5** Manage Stakeholders inputs/outputs and main roles

**Outputs**

- Project Stakeholder Matrix (updated) ☑
- Issue and Decision Logs (updated) ☑
- Stakeholders Checklist ☑

sections.title: Manage Requirements
sections.markdown:
Requirements management is the process of gathering, documenting, validating and managing requirement changes throughout the project lifecycle. It relates closely to quality and change management.
The process can be tailored and documented in either a Requirements Management Plan or the Project Handbook.

**Key Participants**

| Participant | Description |
|-------------|-------------|
| Project Manager (PM) | Leads requirements management. |
| Business Manager (BM) | Provides and approves business requirements. |
| User Representatives (URs) | Participate in gathering and validating requirements. |
| Business Analyst (BA) | Handles documentation and analysis. |

#### Inputs

- Project Initiation Request, Business Case & Charter
- Requirements Management Plan
- Project Stakeholder Matrix

#### Guidelines

- Requirements must describe **needs**, not **solutions**.
- Baseline requirements = baseline project scope.
- Each requirement should have a corresponding acceptance test.
- Any change to baselined requirements must follow the Change Management process.

#### Steps

1. **Specify** requirements and document them clearly.
2. **Evaluate** feasibility, consistency, completeness and cost/effort.
3. **Approve** the requirements with stakeholders.
4. **Monitor** implementation and update as required.
5. **Validate** implemented requirements via acceptance tests.

![](/pm2/figures/fig-9-6.png)

**Fig 9.6** Manage Requirements inputs/outputs and main roles

**Outputs**

- Change Log (updated) ☑
- Project Work Plan (updated) ☑

sections.title: Manage Project Change
sections.markdown:
Project change management defines the activities related to identifying, documenting, assessing, prioritising, approving, planning and controlling changes. Changes can be raised by any stakeholder.
The Change Log records, tracks and communicates all changes.

**Key Participants**

| Participant | Description |
|-------------|-------------|
| Project Manager (PM) | Controls project changes. |
| Project Owner (PO) and/or PSC | Approves or rejects changes. |
| Project Core Team (PCT) | Assesses effort and impact. |
| Stakeholders | Informed; can propose changes. |

#### Inputs

- Business Case & Project Charter
- Change Management Process
- Project Work Plan
- Communications Management Plan
- Relevant logs (e.g. Issue Log)

#### Steps

1. **Identify** the change and document it.
2. **Assess** the change and recommend actions.
3. **Approve** (or reject, postpone, merge) via governance.
4. **Implement** approved changes and update logs.
5. **Control** changes and maintain communication.

![](/pm2/figures/fig-9-7.png)

**Fig 9.7** Manage Project Change inputs/outputs and main roles

**Outputs**

- Change Request Form ☑
- Change Log (updated) ☑
- Project Work Plan (updated) ☑

sections.title: Manage Risk
sections.markdown:
Risk management is a systematic, ongoing process to identify, assess and manage risks so they align with the organisation's accepted risk attitude. It strengthens project confidence by proactively addressing potential positive or negative events.
The process can be documented in a Risk Management Plan or the Project Handbook. A Risk Log is used to store and communicate risks, actions and responsibilities.

**Key Participants**

| Participant | Description |
|-------------|-------------|
| Project Manager (PM) | Monitors and controls risks. |
| Other stakeholders | Informed of critical risks. |
| Project Core Team (PCT) | Identifies and responds to risks. |
| Project Steering Committee (PSC) | Monitors projects with high risk exposure. |

#### Inputs

- Business Case & Project Charter
- Risk Management Process
- Risk Log

#### Steps

1. **Identify risks** and add them to the Risk Log.
2. **Assess risks** (likelihood & impact).
3. **Develop risk-response strategy** and plan actions.
4. **Control** risk-response activities and update the Risk Log.
5. **Record** risk-response tasks in the Project Work Plan.
6. **Report** regularly to the PSC.

![](/pm2/figures/fig-9-8.png)

**Fig 9.8** Manage Risk inputs/outputs and main roles

**Outputs**

- Risk Log (updated) ☑

sections.title: Manage Issues and Decisions
sections.markdown:
The PM manages project issues and decisions. Issues are identified, assessed and assigned for resolution according to the Issue Management Process. The Issue Log manages issues; the Decision Log records decisions.
Issues and decisions often relate to risks, changes or acceptance activities.

**Key Participants**

| Participant | Description |
|-------------|-------------|
| Project Manager (PM) | Monitors issues and drives decisions. |
| Project Core Team (PCT) | Reviews action plans and resolves issues. |
| Other stakeholders | Informed about critical issues and major decisions. |

#### Inputs

- Issue Management Process
- Project Logs
- Minutes of Meetings (MoMs)

#### Steps (Issues)

1. Ensure issue management is executed as planned.
2. Identify issues and add to the Issue Log.
3. Escalate high-impact issues to the PSC.
4. Update the Project Work Plan with major issue actions.
5. Monitor and control issue resolution.
6. Update and close issues in the Issue Log.
7. Report issue status to stakeholders.

#### Steps (Decisions)

1. Document all major project decisions.
2. Link decisions to related risks/issues/changes.
3. Report decision status regularly to stakeholders.

![](/pm2/figures/fig-9-9.png)

**Fig 9.9** Manage Issues & Decisions inputs/outputs and main roles

**Outputs**

- Issue Log (updated) ☑
- Decision Log (updated) ☑

sections.title: Manage Quality
sections.markdown:
Project quality management ensures the project achieves expected results efficiently and that deliverables meet defined acceptance criteria. It includes quality planning, assurance, control and improvement across all phases.
The PM ensures all quality activities, metrics and responsibilities are documented in the Quality Management Plan.

**Key Participants**

| Participant | Description |
|-------------|-------------|
| Project Manager (PM) | Ensures all quality controls occur as planned. |
| Project Quality Assurance (PQA) | Reviews project quality. |
| Project Core Team (PCT) | Assists with quality control. |

#### Inputs

- Project Handbook
- Project Work Plan
- Quality Management Plan
- Deliverables Acceptance Plan

#### Steps

1. Define and agree quality characteristics based on needs and constraints.
2. Perform quality assurance and control activities.
3. Verify configuration management procedure adherence.
4. Involve the full team and stakeholders.
5. Identify non-conformities and implement corrective actions.
6. Identify opportunities for improvement.
7. Ensure deliverables meet acceptance criteria.

![](/pm2/figures/fig-9-10.png)

**Fig 9.10** Manage Quality inputs/outputs and main roles

**Outputs**

- Quality Review Checklist ☑
- Phase-exit Review Checklist ☑
- Quality Review Reports -
- Audit Reports -

sections.title: Manage Deliverables Acceptance
sections.markdown:
Deliverables acceptance ensures each deliverable meets the predefined acceptance criteria outlined in the Deliverables Acceptance Plan. Final acceptance occurs in the Closing Phase.

**Key Participants**

| Participant | Description |
|-------------|-------------|
| Project Manager (PM) | Leads the acceptance management process. |
| Project Quality Assurance (PQA) | Conducts quality controls. |
| Project Steering Committee (PSC) | Defines acceptance strategy. |
| Project Owner (PO) | Provides final acceptance. |

#### Inputs

- Deliverables Acceptance Plan
- Project Work Plan
- Quality Management Plan
- Outsourcing Plan (if applicable)

#### Steps

1. PM ensures acceptance procedures and environments are in place.
2. PSC approves acceptance strategy and schedule.
3. Acceptance performed as per plan; conditional acceptance allowed.
4. BM provides resources to support user acceptance.
5. PM ensures supporting deliverables (manuals, training, documentation) are delivered.
6. PO formally accepts project deliverables.

![](/pm2/figures/fig-9-11.png)

**Fig 9.11** Manage Deliverables Acceptance inputs/outputs and main roles

**Outputs**

- Deliverables Acceptance Checklist ☑
- Decision Log ☑
- Deliverables Acceptance Note -

sections.title: Manage Transition
sections.markdown:
Transition management ensures a controlled move from the old state to the new state where the project's outputs are fully operational. It requires close cooperation between the PM and the BM, and ensures the correct handover to the client organisation.

**Key Participants**

| Participant | Description |
|-------------|-------------|
| Project Manager (PM) | Monitors and controls the transition. |
| Project Quality Assurance (PQA) | Involved where necessary. |
| Other stakeholders | Informed and contribute as needed. |
| Project Owner (PO) | Provisionally accepts the product before transition is complete. |

#### Inputs

- Transition Plan
- Project Work Plan
- Communications Management Plan
- Deliverables Acceptance Plan
- Business Implementation Plan

#### Steps

1. Ensure acceptance criteria are met and deliverables are operational.
2. Ensure the Transition Plan is executed effectively.
   - Identify roles and stakeholders.
   - Define what must be achieved before transition completion.
   - Prepare backups and rollback scenarios (if applicable).
   - Ensure business implementation and training activities occur.
   - Coordinate communication and release activities.
   - Ensure maintenance/support begins as planned.
   - Ensure documentation/material is handed over.
3. Ensure PO provisionally accepts deliverables.
4. Transfer ownership and responsibility to the PO.
5. Ensure all acceptance documents are complete.

![](/pm2/figures/fig-9-12.png)

**Fig 9.12** Manage Transition inputs/outputs and main roles

**Outputs**

- Transition Checklist ☑
- Additional transition records/reports -
- Acceptance documents (as required) -

sections.title: Manage Business Implementation
sections.markdown:
Business implementation ensures that all activities required for operational readiness are completed. These activities complement transition activities and often continue beyond the project.

**Key Participants**

| Participant | Description |
|-------------|-------------|
| Business Manager (BM) | Manages business implementation activities. |
| Project Manager (PM) | Assists and updates the Work Plan with changes. |

#### Inputs

- Business Implementation Plan
- Project Handbook
- Project Work Plan
- Transition Plan

#### Steps

1. Ensure the Business Implementation Plan is complete and realistic.
2. Ensure all activities within project scope are defined, scheduled and resourced.
3. Focus on activities within project duration and budget.
4. Manage execution of business implementation activities:
   - Update business processes.
   - Execute communication activities.
   - Deliver organisational change activities.
   - Ensure training is completed.
   - Manage business continuity plans.
5. Report on the status of business implementation activities.

![](/pm2/figures/fig-9-13.png)

**Fig 9.13** Manage Business Implementation inputs/outputs and main roles

**Outputs**

- Business Implementation Checklist ☑
- Project Work Plan (updated) ☑

sections.title: Manage Outsourcing
sections.markdown:
The PM manages all outsourced work, ensuring timely, cost-effective and quality delivery. This is done in cooperation with procurement groups and the Contractor's Project Manager (CPM).

**Key Participants**

| Participant | Description |
|-------------|-------------|
| Project Manager (PM) | Manages contractor performance. |
| Contractor’s PM (CPM) | Delivers outsourced work to required quality. |
| Project Quality Assurance (PQA) | Performs quality controls. |

#### Inputs

- Outsourcing Plan
- Business Case & Project Charter
- Project Work Plan

#### Steps

1. PSC ensures contractor selection follows organisational standards.
2. PSC ensures contracts clearly define expectations.
3. PM applies working methods defined in the Outsourcing Plan.
4. PM monitors costs and schedules.
5. CPM reports progress to PM and PSC.
6. PM manages changes to outsourced work.
7. PM and/or PSC validate interim and final deliverables.
8. PM ensures formal approvals are received as required.

![](/pm2/figures/fig-9-14.png)

**Fig 9.14** Manage Outsourcing inputs/outputs and main roles

**Outputs**

- Status & Progress Report(s) ☑
- Signed contracts -
- Signed purchase orders -
- Signed timesheets -
